comments.body:
Instead of applying this mock everywhere, inject it into the testbed constructor overrides in the testfile:

```
testbed = Testbed(setup: () { ... }, overrides: <Type, Generator>{ ... here })
```
Per discussion, this should be in the testbed, but it's a fake, not a mock, so I renamed it as such.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +34,38 @@      ? FileSystemStyle.windows
      : FileSystemStyle.posix),
  Logger: () => BufferLogger(), // Allows reading logs and prevents stdout.
  OperatingSystemUtils: () => FakeOperatingSystemUtils(),
  OutputPreferences: () => OutputPreferences(showColor: false), // configures BufferLogger to avoid color codes.

comments.body: Maybe add example usage to the comments, or point at a simple reference example.
Added an example and more documentation

Some tests that use 'is' checks to make sure that the overrides work as documented would be good. What will/should happen with different combos of overrides appearing {in the default list above, in the Testbed constructor, in the run call}?

Can we remove or DRY out the other places attempting this since it's already mocked in the outer zone? MockHttpClient, MockHttpClientRequest, MockHttpClientResponse in create_test.dart and context.dart, _MockHttpClient in binding, etc.

The Mocks and Fakes shouldn't be used interchangeably. The former have the potential to have behaviors added dynamically (via mock/noSuchMethod) that can leak between tests, while the later is safe to reuse across test runs.

The _MockHttpClient in binding.dart should be renamed _FakeHttpClient (that one is my fault). But it can't be shared because flutter_test has a dependency on dart:ui, which doesn't exist on the command line where the tool runs.

Any cleanup we do would be to simplify/remove the mocks in context and create_test.

Bleh it's a shame fakes is How It's Done with Dart testing since now you're on the hook for overriding all new methods, and also a shame that [MockClient](https://pub.dev/documentation/http/latest/testing/MockClient-class.html) doesn't look very useful.
Ideally the HttpClient* classes would be extendable, but they are just interfaces so we're on the hook for everything.
